
The various definition statements recognized by the IMP interpreter are presented in this chapter. The first word of each statement is a keyword instructing the IMP system to interpret the remainder of the statement according to one of the formats on the following pages.

==The &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines one rigid link of the system.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; = link name
where ''link name'' refers to an alphanumeric name given to the link.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; = PART
defines a link named ''PART'' to be a part of the system model.

===Notes===
# Use of the &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is optional. Links may also be defined by the use of their ''link name'' in a statement defining a joint.
# If the ''link name'' used in a &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement has not been previously defined, a new link is created and assigned that ''link name''.
# No other link may be defined having the same ''link name''. If an attempt is made to do so, no new link results; a warning message is printed instead.
# Each link of the system has attached to it a unique coordinate system which moves whenever the link moves. At the time of its first creation by a &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement or a joint definition statement, this link coordinate system is assumed coincident with the global coordinate system. It may be moved to another location or orientation by use of a &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# One or more &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statements may be given to provide shape(s) to the link defined with this ''link name''. If such a &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not found, the ''link name'' has no defined shape. Points may still be attached to the link in such a case, however, and their locations may still be defined relative to the link coordinate system. Using such points, a schematic representation may be drawn for the link. However, a solid shape for the link is not known, and collision with other link shapes cannot be detected.
# Each ''link name'' defined must be attached, either directly or indirectly, by properly defined joints to the fixed link. If a ''link name'' does not appear in at least one valid joint definition statement, the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement causes a message to be printed and that link (along with any data dependent on it) to be deleted from the system.


==The &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; statement designates the link which remains stationary, that is, the link which contains the global coordinate system.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; = link name
where ''link name'' is the alphanumeric name assigned to the fixed link.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; = FRAME
The link named ''FRAME'' is selected as the fixed link of the system.

===Notes===
# The use of the &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; statement is optional. Although every IMP simulation model must contain a fixed link, IMP recognizes the name &lt;tt&gt;BASE&lt;/tt&gt; as designating the fixed link unless overridden by a &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# Not more than one ''link name'' may be defined as stationary. If the &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; statement appears more than once, only the most recent &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; statement is in effect at any time. Thus, the &lt;tt&gt;GROUND&lt;/tt&gt; statement can be used to perform kinematic inversion.
# All remaining links of the system must be attached by properly defined joints to the fixed link. If a ''link name'' does not appear in at least one valid joint definition statement, the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement causes a message to be printed and the link (and any data dependent on it) to be deleted from the system model.
# Each link of the system has attached to it a unique coordinate system which moves whenever the link moves. At the time of its first creation by a &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement or a joint definition statement, this link coordinate system is assumed to be coincident with the global coordinate system. It may be moved to another location or orientation by use of a &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.


==The &lt;tt&gt;SOLID READ&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;SOLID READ&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines one or more solid shapes with data stored in a previously prepared file.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;SOLID READ&lt;/tt&gt; (solid name) = filename
where ''solid name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to the solid, and ''filename'' is the name of the file containing data for the solid to be read. The file may be in either the JML standard 3-D Solid file format (Appendix A) with ''filename'' extension of ''.geo'', or in the stereo-lithography (&lt;tt&gt;STL&lt;/tt&gt;) standard file format with ''filename'' extension of ''.stl''.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;SOLID READ&lt;/tt&gt; (PART) = shape.geo
defines a solid named ''PART'' with data from a previously prepared JML format file named ''shape.geo''.

===Notes===
# The solid named ''solid name'' defined by ''filename'' is assumed to be attached to the stationary link unless defined otherwise by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The data read from the file is assumed referenced to the coordinate system of the link to which the solid is attached unless modified by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The ''filename'' used must refer to a previously prepared file containing data for the solid shape; this file must be prepared in either the JML standard 3-D Solid file format (Appendix A) with the ''filename'' extension of ''.geo'', or in the stereo-lithography (&lt;tt&gt;STL&lt;/tt&gt;) standard file format with the ''filename'' extension of ''.stl''. If such a file is not found or cannot be read, no solid is created; a message is printed.
# If the JML standard file format is used it is possible that more than one solid may be contained in the file. If so, multiple solid shapes are created in the system model with ''solid names'' defined in the file. The ''solid name'' defined in the &lt;tt&gt;SOLID READ&lt;/tt&gt; statement will override the ''solid name'' from the file for the first solid shape read.


==The &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a geometry for a link or for one part of a link.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name) = solid1, solid2, ...
where ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to the link and each ''solid name'' is the name of a previously defined solid defining the shape of that part of the link.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; (PART) = bar, ball
defines the shape of a link named ''PART'' to be composed of two previously defined solids named ''bar'' and ''ball''.

===Notes===
# When each solid is first defined by a &lt;tt&gt;SOLID&lt;/tt&gt; statement it is assumed to be part of the fixed link until it is attached to some other link by a &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# It is necessary to refer to each ''solid name'' in a &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement for the attachment of that solid to its corresponding ''link name''.
# A maximum of 33 ''solid names'' may be defined in a single &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement (with continuation lines). There is no restriction, however, on defining additional ''solid names'' attached to the same ''link name'' with one or more additional &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statements.
# If the same ''solid name'' is used in more than one &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement, the most recent occurrence of that ''solid name'' takes precedence and earlier relationships are replaced.
# Each ''solid name'' may be given a location on the ''link name'' by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If this is not done before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, then ''shape names'' are defined with their coordinate data measured with respect to the link coordinate system.
# ''Solid names'' attached to different ''link names'' may not be defined in the same &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The ''link name'' referred to in a &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement must have appeared in at least one previous &lt;tt&gt;LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement or a statement defining a joint. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a logical association between two solid shapes of different links which may be monitored for possible collision during the motion of the system.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; (solid name, solid name) = contact name
where each ''solid name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two solid shapes and ''contact name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the contact.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; (KNOB, POCKET) = BUMPER
defines a contact named ''BUMPER'' between two shapes named ''KNOB'' and ''POCKET''.

===Notes===
# &lt;tt&gt;A CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is never required, but may be useful to form an association between two link shapes of the system such that a possible collision may be detected and proper momentum transfer can be simulated.
# Each contact in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other contact may be defined having the same ''contact name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined contact of the same ''contact name'' (and all data associated with it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''solid name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a contact.
# Each &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement must refer to two distinct ''solid names'' of solids on two different links. An attempt to associate a solid shape with itself or with another solid shape on the same link causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# The order in which the two ''solid names'' appear is arbitrary.
# Each &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement should be associated with a corresponding &lt;tt&gt;DATA CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the coefficient of restitution normal to the surface is unity and all other contact data is zero. No message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;IMPACT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;IMPACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is used to specify the nature of the change of momentum equations to be used at the moment of collision between contacting solids defined by &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statements.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;IMPACT&lt;/tt&gt; = ktangent, kmoment, ktorsion
where ''ktangent'', ''kmoment'', and ''ktorsion'' define the types of models to be used for tangential, moment, and torsional impulses, respectively, at modeled contacts; each may be chosen as 0 for undefined, 1 for a coefficient of restitution model, 2 for a Coulomb friction model, or 3 for a bilinear restitution and Coulomb friction model.

; Example: &lt;tt&gt;IMPACT&lt;/tt&gt; = 2, 1, 3
specifies that the mathematical model used for simulating impacts at each &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; will be Coulomb friction for any tangential impulses, coefficient of restitution for moment impulses, and bilinear for torsional impulses.

===Notes===
# An &lt;tt&gt;IMPACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement should be defined for any model which includes a &lt;tt&gt;CONTACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If this does not appear before the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement, any tangential, moment, or torsional impulses found within contacts are ignored.
# If more than one &lt;tt&gt;IMPACT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, the later statement takes precedence; earlier data are replaced; no message is printed.
# If integer values other than 0 through 3 are used for ''ktangent'', ''kmoment'', or ''ktorsion'', no error is detected immediately. However 0 is used for the offending value and corresponding impulses are ignored; no message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_1.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-1:'' Example of a rigid joint.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a non-movable joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-1).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = WELD
defines a rigid joint named ''WELD'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each rigid joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The two coordinate systems may be located and oriented arbitrarily but both coordinate systems must be coincident (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system. No message is printed.
# The &lt;tt&gt;RIGID&lt;/tt&gt; joint is immobile and has no joint variables.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint. (See, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).


==The &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_2.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-2:'' Example of a pinned joint parallel to the X axis.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a pinned joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-2), with its pin axis initally parallel to the global X axis.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = PIN
defines a pinned joint named ''PIN'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each X-oriented pin joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The origins of the two local coordinate systems must be coincident, the local u and u' axes must be collinear and initially parallel to the global X axis and must be directed along the joint axis, and both local u axes must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system. No message is printed.
# The joint variable for an &lt;tt&gt;XPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the angle from the positive local v axis to the positive local v' axis. It has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local u,u' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (rotation of the joint).


==The &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_3.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-3:'' Example of a pinned joint parallel to the Y axis.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a pinned joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-3), with
its pin axis initially parallel to the global Y axis.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = PIN
defines a pinned joint named ''PIN'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each Y-oriented pin joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The origins of the two local coordinate systems must be coincident, the local v and v' axes must be collinear and initially parallel to the global Y axis and must be directed along the joint axis, and both local v axes must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;YPIN&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the angle from the positive local w axis to the positive local w' axis. It has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local v,v' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (rotation of the joint).

This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).

==The &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_5.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-5:'' Example of a pin joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a pin joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-5).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = PIN
defines a pinned joint named ''PIN'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each revolute joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The origins of the two local coordinate systems must be coincident the local w and w' axes must be collinear and must be directed along the joint axis and both local w axes must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;REVOLUTE&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the angle from the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis. It has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w,w' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (rotation of the joint).


==The &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_6.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-6:'' Example of a sliding joint with its axis parallel to the X axis.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a sliding joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-6), with its axis initially parallel to the global X axis.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = SLIP
defines a sliding joint named ''SLIP'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each X-oriented sliding joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local u and u' axes must be collinear and parallel to the global X axis and must both be directed parallel to the relative motion of the joint. Both local u axes must have the same positive sense, and the local v and v' axes must be parallel and must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# The joint variable for an &lt;tt&gt;XSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the distance from the positive local v axis to the positive local v' axis. It has units of length and is considered positive when in the same direction as the positive local u,u' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (sliding motion of the joint).

==The &lt;tt&gt;YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_7.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-7:'' Example of a sliding joint with its axis parallel to the Y axis.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a sliding joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-7), with its axis initially parallel to the global Y axis.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = SLIP
defines a sliding joint named ''SLIP'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each Y-oriented sliding joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local v and v' axes must be collinear and initially parallel to the global Y axis and must both be directed parallel to the relative motion of the joint. Both local v axes must have the same positive sense, and the local w and w' axes must be parallel and must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system. No message is printed.
# The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;YSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the distance from the positive local w axis to the positive local w' axis. It has units of length and is considered positive when in the same direction as the positive local v,v' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (sliding motion of the joint).

[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_8.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-8:'' Example of a sliding joint with its axis parallel to the Z axis.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a sliding joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-8), with its pin axis initially parallel to be global Z axis.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

 &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = SLIP
defines a sliding joint named ''SLIP'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each Z-oriented sliding joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.

Both local u axes must have the same positive sense, and the local u and u' axes must be parallel and must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system. No message is printed.
# The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;ZSLIDE&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the distance from the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis. It has units of length and is considered positive when in the same direction as the positive local w,w' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (sliding motion of the joint).


==The &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_9.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-9:'' Example of a sliding joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a sliding joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-9).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.
