 &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = SLIP
defines a sliding joint named ''SLIP'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each prismatic joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a warning message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must be collinear and must both be directed parallel to the relative motion of the joint. Both local w axes must have the same positive sense, and the local u and u' axes must be parallel and must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate systems(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system. No message is printed.
# The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;PRISM&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the distance from the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis. It has units of length and is considered positive when in the same direction as the positive local w,w' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the sign of the joint variable and its derivatives (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the magnitude of the joint variable (sliding motion of the joint).


==The &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_10.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-10:'' Example of a gear joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a gear joint between two links of the system (see figure 3-10).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the gear joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; (SUN, PLAN) = SPUR
defines a gear joint named ''SPUR'' connecting two links named ''SUN'' and ''PLAN''.

===Notes===
# Each gear joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must coincide with the centers of the first and second ''link names'', respectively, and must both be positively directed on the same side of the gears. The local u,v and u',v' axes must all lie in a common plane parallel to the plane of motion of the two gears. The line of centers of the two gears through the local origins is defined as t and is positive in the sense defined from w to w'. The local u and u' axes must be chosen such that, at one position of the gear joint, positive local u, positive local u', and positive t all lie along the same line and have the same sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system(s); no message is printed.
# A &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint has one internal degree of freedom. The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the angle from the positive local u axis to positive t. It has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w axis.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variable (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the rotation of the joint variable.
# The gear ratio of each &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint must be defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The simulation of the &lt;tt&gt;GEAR&lt;/tt&gt; joint is treated as though they are two cylinders rolling against each other with no slip. This causes no problem in motion analysis; however, in force analysis, the gears are treated as having zero pressure angle.


==The &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_11.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-11:'' Example of a bevel gear joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a bevel gear joint between two links of the system (see figure 3-11).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; (SUN, PLAN) = BVL
defines a bevel gear joint named ''BVL'' connecting two links named ''SUN'' and ''PLAN''.

===Notes===
# Each bevel gear joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must coincide with the pitch cone axes directed outward from their common apexes. The local u,v and u',v' axes must lie in the planes of the pitch circles of the first and second ''link names'', respectively. The local u and u' axes must be chosen such that, at one position of the bevel gear joint, the positive local u axis is directed toward the pitch point and the positive local u' axis is directed away from the pitch point at that position of the bevel gears; u,w,w' and u' all lie in the plane defined by the two cone axes.
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# A &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint has one internal degree of freedom. The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the angle from the positive local u axis to the positive local w' axis. It has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w axis.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variable (see Note 7 above), and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see, for example, the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the rotation of the joint variable.
# The gear ratio and pitch circle radius of each &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint must be defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The simulation of a &lt;tt&gt;BEVEL&lt;/tt&gt; joint is treated as though the two pitch cones are rolling against each other with no slip. This causes no problem in motion analysis; however, in force analysis, the bevel gears are treated as having zero presure angle.


==The &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_12.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-12:'' Example of a rack and pinion joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a rack and pinion joint between two links of the system (see figure 3-12).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; (RAIL, WHEL) = MESH
defines a rack and pinion joint named ''MESH'' connecting a link named ''RAIL'' (the rack) with a link named ''WHEL'' (the pinion).

===Notes===
# Each rack and pinion joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# The first ''link name'' must be that of the rack, and the second ''link name'' refers to the pinion link the order is not arbitrary and cannot be reversed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local u axis must lie in the plane of the pitch circle of the pinion, along the pitch line of the rack, while the local w axis is perpendicular to the plane of the pitch circle and the local v axis is in the plane of the pitch circle and positively directed toward the pinion side of u. The local w' axis coincides with the center of the pitch circle and is parallel to and positively directed the same as w. The local u' and v' axes lie in the plane of and radiate from the center of the pitch circle of the pinion. The line parallel to u through the center of the pitch circle and positively directed in the same sense as u is defined as t. The local coordinate systems must be chosen such that, at one position of the &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint, the positive local u axis is aligned along positive t and the pinion center lies on the local v axis with positive v' directed in the same sense as the positive local v axis (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# A &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint has one internal degree of freedom. The joint variable for a &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint is the distance from the v axis along positive t to the local v' origin. It has units of length and is considered positive when in the positive u direction.
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the travel of the joint variable.
# The pitch circle radius of the pinion must be defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA RACK&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The simulation of a &lt;tt&gt;RACK&lt;/tt&gt; joint is treated as though the pinion is a cylinder rolling without slip against a smooth plane for the rack. This causes no problem in motion analysis; however, in force analysis, the pinion is treated as having zero pressure angle.


==The &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_13.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-13:'' Example of a screw joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a screw joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-13).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; (BOLT, NUT) = THRD
defines a screw joint named ''THRD'' connecting two links named ''BOLT'' and ''NUT''.

===Notes===
# Each screw joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must be collinear and must be directed along the joint axis; both must have the same positive sense. The local u and u' axes must be chosen such that, at one position of the joint, they are collinear and the two local origins coincide (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# The joint variable for a joint is the distance from the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis. It has units of length and is considered positive when in the same direction as the positive local w,w' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variable (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the travel of the joint variable.
# The lead of the screw thread of each &lt;tt&gt;SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; joint must be defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA SCREW&lt;/tt&gt; statement. Notice that the sign of the lead distinguishes a right-hand from a left-hand thread.


==The &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_14.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-14:'' Example of a cam and follower joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a cam and follower joint between two links of the system (see figure 3-14).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; (DISK, ROLR) = CURV
defines a &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint named ''CURV'' connecting a cam shaped link named ''DISK'' with a follower link named ''ROLR''.

===Notes===
# Each cam and follower joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# The first ''link name'' referenced must be that with the cam profile and the second ''link name'' refers to the follower link the order is not arbitrary and cannot be reversed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must both lie normal to the plane of the pitch curve and both must be positively directed on the same side of this plane. The local u,v and u',v' axes must all lie in this same plane; the (u,v,w) local origin may be located arbitrarily on the first ''link name'' but the (u',v',w') local origin must be located on the pitch curve. The line directed from the origin of (u,v,w) to the origin of (u',v',w') is defined as positive t (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# A &lt;tt&gt;CAM&lt;/tt&gt; joint has two internal degrees of freedom. The first joint variable is the angle from the positive local u axis to positive t; it has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w axis. The second joint variable is the angle from positive t to the positive local u' axis; it has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w' axis.
# It is assumed there are no limits on the rotation of either joint variable.
# The shape of the pitch curve (see figure) must be defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA CAM&lt;/tt&gt; statement.


==The &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_15.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-15:'' Example of a pin-in-slot joint between two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a pin-in-slot joint between two links of the system (see figure 3-15).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.
===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; (PLAT, BAR) = CURV
defines a &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint named ''CURV'' connecting a profile slotted link named ''PLAT'' with a follower link named ''BAR''.

===Notes===
# Each slot joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# The first ''link name'' referenced must be that containing the slot profile and the second ''link name'' refers to the follower link; the order is not arbitrary and cannot be reversed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must both lie normal to the plane of the profiled slot and both must be positively directed on the same side of the plane. The local u,v and u',v' axes must all lie in this same plane the (u,v,w) local origin may be located arbitrarily on the first ''link name'', but the (u',v',w') local origin must be located on the centerline of the profiled slot (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before the &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# A &lt;tt&gt;SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; joint has two internal degrees of freedom. The first joint variable is the u projection of the distance from the first local coordinate origin to the second local coordinate origin it has units of length and is considered positive if in the same direction as the positive local u axis. The second joint variable is the angle from a line paralleling the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis it has units of degrees and considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w' axis.
# It is assumed there are no limits on the travel of either joint variable (see notes for the &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# The shape of the profiled slot in the first ''link name'' must be defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA SLOT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.


==The &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_16.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-16:'' Example of a cylindric joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a cylindric joint (allowing turning and sliding motions about and along a common axis) connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-16).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; (LK1, LK2) = CYL
defines a cylindric joint named ''CYL'' connecting two links named ''LK1'' and ''LK2''.

===Notes===
# Each cylindric joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it) a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; ''joint name'' (see figure) and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The local w and w' axes must be collinear and must be directed along the axis of relative motion of the joint. Both local w axes must have the same positive sense (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# Each &lt;tt&gt;CYLINDER&lt;/tt&gt; joint has two internal degrees of freedom. The first joint variable is the angle from the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis. It has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w,w' axes. The second joint variable is the distance from the local u axis to the local u' axis measured along the common local w,w' axes it has units of length and is considered positive when the relative displacement is in the same sense as the positive local w,w' axes.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variables (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the travel of either joint variable.


==The &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_17.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-17:'' Example of a universal joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a Hooke universal joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-17).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; (SHFT, ROD) = UJNT
defines a Hooke universal joint named ''UJNT'' connecting two links named ''SHFT'' and ''ROD''.

===Notes===
# Each universal joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it) a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; ''joint name'' (see figure) and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The origins of the two local coordinate systems must be coincident; the local w and w' axes must coincide with the two pin axes on the cross of the universal joint and they must be mutually perpendicular. The common perpendicular to the local w and w' axes is defined as t and is positive in the direction specified by the right hand rule applied from positive w to positive w' (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered, it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# A &lt;tt&gt;UJOINT&lt;/tt&gt; joint has two internal degrees of freedom. The first joint variable is the angle from the positive local u axis to positive t it has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from positive w. The second joint variable is the angle from positive t to the positive local u' axis it also has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive w' axis.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variables (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there is no limit on the rotation of either of the joint variables.


==The &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_18.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-18:'' Example of a flat joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a flat joint (two flat surfaces constrained to remain in contact but free to turn and slide in the plane) connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-18).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; (BASE, PAD) = PLATE
defines a &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; joint named ''PLATE'' connecting two links named ''BASE'' and ''PAD''.

===Notes===
# Each flat joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each &lt;tt&gt;FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The u,v and u',v' planes must be chosen coplanar and parallel to the mating surfaces of the joint the local w and w' axes must be parallel and must be directed to the same side of the mating surfaces (see figure).
# Care should be taken in choosing the two local coordinate systems to insure that, as the joint moves, the origins of the two local coordinate systems never become coincident. If these origins do become coincident the first and third joint variables become redundant (see note 8 below, and see figure); numeric difficulties may be encountered at or very near to such a position.
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# &lt;tt&gt;A FLAT&lt;/tt&gt; joint has three internal degrees of freedom. The common perpendicular between the local w and w' axes is designated as t. The first joint variable is the angle from the positive local u axis to positive t; it has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from positive local w. The second joint variable is the distance from w to w' measured along t; it has units of length and is considered positive when measured in the same sense as positive t. The third joint variable is the angle from positive t to positive local u'; it has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w' axis (see figure).
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variables (see Note 8 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there are no limits on the travel of any of the joint variables.


==The &lt;tt&gt;PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_19.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-19:'' Example of a planar joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a planar joint (two flat surfaces constrained to remain in contact but free to turn and slide in the plane) connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-19).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; (BASE, PAD) = PLATE
defines a planar joint named ''PLATE'' connecting two links named ''BASE'' and ''PAD''.

===Notes===
# Each planar joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each &lt;tt&gt;PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The u,v and u',v' planes must be chosen coplanar and parallel to the mating surfaces of the joint; the local w and w' axes must be parallel and must be directed to the same side of the mating surfaces (see figure).
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# &lt;tt&gt;A PLANE&lt;/tt&gt; joint has three internal degrees of freedom. The first and second joint variables are the u and v components, respectively, of the location of the (u',v',w') origin with respect to the (u,v,w) axes. These have units of length and are considered positive according to the sense of the u and v axes. The third joint variable is the angle from a line parallel to the positive local u axis to the positive local u' axis it has units of degrees and is considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive local w' axis (see figure).
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variables (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there are no limits on the travel of any of the joint variables.


==The &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_20.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-20:'' Example of a ball and socket joint connecting two links.]]
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_21.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-21:'' Kinematically equivalent model of a ball and socket joint connecting two links.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a ball and socket joint connecting two links of the system (see figure 3-20, 3-21).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two connected links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; (BALL, SCKT) = SPHR
defines a spheric joint named ''SPHR'' connecting two links named ''BALL'' and ''SCKT''.

===Notes===
# Each spheric joint in the system must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; ''joint name'' (see figure), and defined by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. The origins of the two local coordinate systems must be coincident with the center of the spheric joint. Care should be taken in choosing the coordinate systems such that, as the joint moves, the local u and w' axes never become collinear. If these axes do become collinear, the first and third joint variables become redundant (see Note 8 below, and see figure). Numeric difficulties may be encountered at or very near to such a position.
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# A spheric joint has three internal degrees of freedom. The three joint variables are the three Eulerian angles describing the relative orientation of the local coordinate systems (see figure). All three joint variables have units of degrees and are considered positive when counterclockwise as seen from the positive ends of the local u axis, the line of nodes, and the local w' axis, respectively.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variables (see Note 7 above) and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there are no limits on the rotations of any of the joint variables.


==The &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
[[Image:Manual_figure_ch3_22.png|thumb|400px|''Figure 3-22:'' Example of a logical association between two links without physical constraints.]]
The &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a logical association between two links of the system without producing any physical constraints (see figure 3-22).

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; (link name, link name) = joint name
where each ''link name'' refers to the alphanumeric name given to one of the two associated links and ''joint name'' is an arbitrarily chosen alphanumeric name assigned to the joint.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; (BASE, BALL) = FREE
defines a logical association named ''FREE'' between two links named ''BASE'' and ''BALL''.

===Notes===
# An &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; statement is never required, but may be useful to form an association between two links of the system such that, for example, some of the variables can be driven with a prescribed motion while others remain free.
# No other joint of any type may be defined having the same ''joint name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined joint of the same ''joint name'' (and all information dependent on it); a message is printed.
# The same ''link name'' may appear in more than one statement defining a joint.
# Each statement defining a joint must refer to two distinct ''link names''. An attempt to join a link to itself causes the statement to be ignored and a message to be printed.
# Two local coordinate systems must be chosen for each &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; ''joint name'' (see figure) and defined by two subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statements. One local coordinate system (u,v,w) is rigidly attached to the first ''link name'', while the other (u',v',w') is rigidly attached to the second ''link name''. Care should be taken in choosing the coordinate systems such that, as the joint moves, the local u and w' axes never become parallel. If these axes do become parallel the fourth and sixth joint variables become redundant (see note 7 below, and see figure). Numeric difficulties may be encountered at or very near to such a position.
# If an appropriate &lt;tt&gt;DATA LINK&lt;/tt&gt; statement is not defined before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is encountered it is assumed that the corresponding local coordinate system(s) is (are) coincident with the link coordinate system; no message is printed.
# An &lt;tt&gt;OPEN&lt;/tt&gt; joint has six internal degrees of freedom. The first three joint variables are the u, v, and w components of the location (translation) of the u',v',w' local origin with respect to the u,v,w axes, respectively. These three variables have units of length and are considered positive according to the senses of the positive local u, v, and w axes. The final three joint variables are the three Eulerian angles describing the relative orientation of the local These three angles are coordinate systems (see figure). defined identically to those of the &lt;tt&gt;SPHERE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The order in which the two ''link names'' appear is arbitrary. This choice, however, does affect the designation of the joint variables (see Note 7 above), and also the signs of the constraint force and torque components within the joint (see the &lt;tt&gt;PRINT FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement).
# It is assumed that there are no limits on the travel of any of the joint variables.


==The &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines one or more points of interest attached to one link of the system model. This statement can also be used to define lines to be drawn by the &lt;tt&gt;DRAW&lt;/tt&gt; statement.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; (link name) = point name, point name, point name, ...
where ''link name'' is the alphanumeric name of the link to which the points are attached and each ''point name'' is an arbitrarily selected alphanumeric name for one of the points being defined. If more than one ''point name'' is listed, the order of the ''point names'' also defines a series of straight line segments to be drawn by subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DRAW&lt;/tt&gt; statements.

; Examples
: &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; (LEVR) = PT1
: &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; (BASE) = A, B, P, PT2, Q
These two statements define a point named ''PT1'' attached to a link named ''LEVR'', and five points named ''A'', ''B'', ''P'', ''PT2'', and ''Q'' attached to another link named ''BASE''. If a &lt;tt&gt;DRAW&lt;/tt&gt; statement is issued, the above statements cause no lines to be drawn for link ''LEVR''; however, the link named ''BASE'' will be drawn as a series of straight line segments from ''A'' to ''B'' to ''P'' to ''PT2'' to ''Q''.

===Notes===
# Each point to be referenced by its ''point name'' in an IMP model must be defined by a &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# It is necessary to define ''point names'' for the attachment points of every spring or damper, for the points of application of every force, and to define the direction of every force or torque. Also, it is often useful to define ''point names'' so that their motions can be printed, so that their locations can be used in supplying data, or to control the visible outline of a link when using the &lt;tt&gt;DRAW&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# A maximum of 33 ''point names'' may be defined in a single &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement (with continuation lines). There is no restriction, however, on defining additional ''point names'' attached to the same ''link name'' with one or more additional &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statements.
# The same ''point name'' may be used more than once, either in the same or in different &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statements. This is often useful when defining a closed figure for the &lt;tt&gt;DRAW&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If the same ''point name'' is defined on more than one link, the first occurrence of that ''point name'' is treated as primary and used for the attachment point of a spring, for example, if requested.
# Each different ''point name'' must be given a location on the ''link name'' by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If this is not done before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, those ''point names'' with missing data are placed coincident with the global origin; no message is printed.
# ''Point names'' attached to different ''link names'' may not be defined in the same &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# There is no restriction against attaching one or more ''point names'' to the stationary ''link name''.
# The ''link name'' referred to in a &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement must have appeared in at least one previous &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement or a statement defining a joint. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The vertices of a link shape defined by a filename in a &lt;tt&gt;SHAPE&lt;/tt&gt; statement have no associated ''point name'' and cannot be referenced as points. An additional coincident point may be defined for this purpose, however, by a &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statement.

==The &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a spring connecting two points of the system.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; (point name, point name) = spring name
where each ''point name'' is the alphanumeric name of one of the two points to which the ends of the spring are attached, and ''spring name'' is an arbitrarily selected alphanumeric name assigned to the spring.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; (PT1, PT2) = PULL
defines a spring named ''PULL'' connected between two points named ''PT1'' and ''PT2''.

===Notes===
# Each spring not acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement) must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# Defining a spring as acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement) is preferable to use of the &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement when possible; the numerical accuracy is better and efficiency is much improved.
# No two springs may be defined having the same ''spring name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined spring with the same ''spring name'' (and associated data) and causes a message to be printed.
# The two ''point names'' used may not be identical; if identical ''point names'' are used the &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The two ''point names'' used must have been defined by previous &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statements. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Each spring defined by a &lt;tt&gt;SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement must be further characterized by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA SPRING&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not appear for each ''spring name'' before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given then any ''spring name'' with missing data is deleted at that time; a message is printed.
# Care should be taken to insure that, as the system moves, the two end points of the spring are never located at the same position since, in such a case, the direction of the spring force becomes undefined. If this does occur during the simulation, the effect of that spring is ignored for that position; a message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines a viscous damper (dashpot) connecting two points of the system.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; (point name, point name) = damper name
where each ''point name'' is the alphanumeric name of one of the two points to which the ends of the damper are attached and ''damper name'' is an arbitrarily selected alphanumeric name assigned to the damper.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; (PT1, PT2) = SLOW
defines a viscous damper named ''SLOW'' connected between two points named ''PT1'' and ''PT2''.

===Notes===
# Each damper not acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement) must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# Defining a damper as acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement) is preferable to use of the &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement when possible; the numerical accuracy is better and efficiency is much improved.
# No two viscous dampers may be defined having the same ''damper name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined damper with the same ''damper name'' (and associated data), and causes a message to be printed.
# The two ''point names'' used may not be identical; if identical ''point names'' are used the &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The two ''point names'' used must have been defined by previous &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statements; if not, the &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Each damper defined by a &lt;tt&gt;DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement must be further characterized by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA DAMPER&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not appear for each ''damper name'' before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, then any ''damper name'' with missing data is deleted at that time; a message is printed.
# Care should be taken to insure that, as the system moves, the two end points of the damper are never located at the same position since, in such a case, the direction of the damper's force becomes undefined. If this does occur during the simulation, the effect of that damper is ignored for that position; a message is printed.


==The &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines an externally applied force acting at a defined point on one link of the system. The direction of the force is defined by two points giving its line of action.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; (point name / point name, point name) = force name
where the first ''point name'' is the alphanumeric name of the point of application of the force and also implicitly defines the link to which the force is applied; the second and third ''point names'' are the alphanumeric names of two points which define the line of action of the force; the ''force name'' is an arbitrarily selected alphanumeric name assigned to the force.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; (PT1 / PT2, PT3) = PUSH
defines a force named ''PUSH'' applied at point ''PT1'' and acting along a line parallel to the line from ''PT2'' to ''PT3''.

===Notes===
# Each externally applied force not acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement) must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# Defining a force as acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement) is preferable to use of the &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement, when possible; the numerical accuracy is better and efficiency is much improved.
# No two forces may be defined having the same ''force name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined force with the same ''force name'' (and associated data) and causes a message to be printed.
# The second and third ''point names'' used may not be identical. If identical ''point names'' are used the statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# There is no restriction against the first and second or first and third ''point names'' used being identical; this may often be desirable.
# The three ''point names'' used must have been defined by previous &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statements. If not, the &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Each externally applied force defined by a &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement must be further characterized by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not appear for each ''force name'' before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given then any ''force name'' with missing data is deleted at that time; a message is printed.
# The second and third ''point names'' serve only to define a line parallel to the force, a direction for the force's line of action. These ''point names'' may be attached to any link(s) of the system including the stationary link.
# Care should be taken to insure that, as the system moves, the second and third ''point names'' used are never located at the same position since, in such a case, the direction of the applied force becomes undefined. If this does occur during the simulation, the effect of that ''force name'' is ignored for that position; a message is printed.
# The force is considered positive when directed from the second ''point name'' toward the third ''point name'' specified in the &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# The reaction force for each ''force name'' is assumed to be applied to the fixed link of the system unless explicitly defined by another &lt;tt&gt;FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.


==The &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; Statement==
The &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement defines an externally applied torque acting on one link of the system. The direction of the torque is also defined by specifying two points which determine the direction of its axis.

===Format===
 &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; (link name / point name, point name) = torque name
where ''link name'' is the alphanumeric name of the link to which the torque is applied; the ''point names'' are the alphanumeric names of each of two points which define a line parallel to the axis of the torque; the ''torque name'' is an arbitrarily selected alphanumeric name assigned to the torque.

===Example===
 &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; (LEVR / PT1, PT2) = TURN
defines a torque named ''TURN'' acting on a link named ''LEVR''; its axis is parallel to the line connecting points named ''PT1'' and ''PT2''.

===Notes===
# Each externally applied torque not acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; statement) must be defined by a separate &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
# Defining a torque as acting within a joint (see &lt;tt&gt;DATA FORCE&lt;/tt&gt; and &lt;tt&gt;DATA TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statements) is preferable to use of the &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement, when possible; the numerical accuracy is better and efficiency is much improved.
# No two torques may be defined having the same ''torque name''. An attempt to do so results in the deletion of the previously defined torque with the same ''torque name'' (and associated data), and causes a message to be printed.
# The two ''point names'' used may not be identical. If identical ''point names'' are used, the statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The ''link name'' used must have been defined in at least one previous statement defining a joint; if not, the &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# The two ''point names'' used must have been defined by previous &lt;tt&gt;POINT&lt;/tt&gt; statements; if not, the &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement is ignored and a message is printed.
# Each externally applied torque defined by a &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement must be further characterized by a subsequent &lt;tt&gt;DATA TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement. If a &lt;tt&gt;DATA TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement does not appear for each ''torque name'' before an &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE&lt;/tt&gt; or &lt;tt&gt;EXECUTE HOLD&lt;/tt&gt; statement is given, then any ''torque name'' with missing data is deleted at that time; a message is printed.
# Either or both of the two ''point names'' used may be attached ''link name'' to which the torque is applied, but this to the is not necessary. Either or both may be attached to any link of the system, including the stationary link.
# Care should be taken that, as the system moves, the two ''point names'' used are never located at the same position since, in such a case, the direction of the axis of the torque becomes undefined. If this does occur during the simulation, the effect of that ''torque name'' is ignored for that position; a message is printed.
# The torque is considered positive when acting counterclockwise (right-hand rule) about the axis directed from the first ''point name'' toward the second ''point name'' specified.
# The reaction torque for each ''torque name'' is assumed applied to the fixed link of the system unless explicitly defined by another &lt;tt&gt;TORQUE&lt;/tt&gt; statement.
